author: Potter
text: What a funny sight it is to see a brood of ducklings with a hen!

author: Potter
text: Listen to the story of Jemima Puddle-duck, who was annoyed because the farmer's wife would not let her hatch her own eggs.

author: Potter
text: Her sister-in-law, Mrs. Rebeccah Puddle-duck, was perfectly willing to leave the hatching to someone else-- "I have not the patience to sit on a nest for twenty-eight days; and no more have you, Jemima.

author: Potter
text: You would let them go cold; you know you would!"

author: Potter
text: "I wish to hatch my own eggs; I will hatch them all by myself," quacked Jemima Puddle-duck.

author: Potter
text: She tried to hide her eggs; but they were always found and carried off.

author: Potter
text: Jemima Puddle-duck became quite desperate.

author: Potter
text: She determined to make a nest right away from the farm.

author: Potter
text: She set off on a fine spring afternoon along the cart road that leads over the hill.

author: Potter
text: She was wearing a shawl and a poke bonnet.

author: Potter
text: When she reached the top of the hill, she saw a wood in the distance.

author: Potter
text: She thought that it looked a safe quiet spot.

author: Potter
text: Jemima Puddle-duck was not much in the habit of flying.

author: Potter
text: She ran downhill a few yards flapping her shawl, and then she jumped off into the air.

author: Potter
text: She flew beautifully when she had got a good start.

author: Potter
text: She skimmed along over the treetops until she saw an open place in the middle of the wood, where the trees and brushwood had been cleared.

author: Potter
text: Jemima alighted rather heavily and began to waddle about in search of a convenient dry nesting place.

author: Potter
text: She rather fancied a tree stump amongst some tall foxgloves.

author: Potter
text: But--seated upon the stump, she was startled to find an elegantly dressed gentleman reading a newspaper.

author: Potter
text: He had black prick ears and sandy colored whiskers.

author: Potter
text: "Quack?" said Jemima Puddle- duck, with her head and her bonnet on the one side--"Quack?"

author: Potter
text: The gentleman raised his eyes above his newspaper and looked curiously at Jemima--

author: Potter
text: "Madam, have you lost your way?" said he.

author: Potter
text: He had a long bushy tail which he was sitting upon, as the stump was somewhat damp.

author: Potter
text: Jemima thought him mighty civil and handsome.

author: Potter
text: She explained that she had not lost her way, but that she was trying to find a convenient dry nesting place.

author: Potter
text: "Ah! is that so?

author: Potter
text: Indeed!" said the gentleman with sandy whiskers, looking curiously at Jemima.

author: Potter
text: He folded up the newspaper and put it in his coattail pocket.

author: Potter
text: Jemima complained of the superfluous hen.

author: Potter
text: "Indeed!

author: Potter
text: How interesting!

author: Potter
text: I wish I could meet with that fowl.

author: Potter
text: I would teach it to mind its own business!

author: Potter
text: "But as to a nest--there is no difficulty: I have a sackful of feathers in my woodshed.

author: Potter
text: No, my dear madam, you will be in nobody's way.

author: Potter
text: You may sit there as long as you like," said the bushy long-tailed gentleman.

author: Potter
text: He led the way to a very retired, dismal-looking house amongst the foxgloves.

author: Potter
text: It was built of faggots and turf, and there were two broken pails, one on top of another, by way of a chimney.

author: Potter
text: "This is my summer residence; you would not find my earth--my winter house--so convenient," said the hospitable gentleman.

author: Potter
text: There was a tumbledown shed at the back of the house, made of old soap boxes.

author: Potter
text: The gentleman opened the door and showed Jemima in.

author: Potter
text: The shed was almost quite full of feathers--it was almost suffocating; but it was comfortable and very soft.

author: Potter
text: Jemima Puddle-duck was rather surprised to find such a vast quantity of feathers.

author: Potter
text: But it was very comfortable; and she made a nest without any trouble at all.

author: Potter
text: When she came out, the sandy- whiskered gentleman was sitting on a log reading the newspaper--at least he had it spread out, but he was looking over the top of it.

author: Potter
text: He was so polite that he seemed almost sorry to let Jemima go home for the night.

author: Potter
text: He promised to take great care of her nest until she came back again the next day.

author: Potter
text: He said he loved eggs and ducklings; he should be proud to see a fine nestful in his woodshed.

author: Potter
text: Jemima Puddle-duck came every afternoon; she laid nine eggs in the nest.

author: Potter
text: They were greeny white and very large.

author: Potter
text: The foxy gentleman admired them immensely.

author: Potter
text: He used to turn them over and count them when Jemima was not there.

author: Potter
text: At last Jemima told him that she intended to begin to sit next day--"and I will bring a bag of corn with me, so that I need never leave my nest until the eggs are hatched.

author: Potter
text: They might catch cold," said the conscientious Jemima.

author: Potter
text: "Madam, I beg you not to trouble yourself with a bag; I will provide oats.

author: Potter
text: But before you commence your tedious sitting, I intend to give you a treat.

author: Potter
text: Let us have a dinner party all to ourselves!

author: Potter
text: "May I ask you to bring up some herbs from the farm garden to make a savory omelet?

author: Potter
text: Sage and thyme, and mint and two onions, and some parsley.

author: Potter
text: I will provide lard for the stuff--lard for the omelet," said the hospitable gentleman with sandy whiskers.

author: Potter
text: Jemima Puddle-duck was a simpleton: not even the mention of sage and onions made her suspicious.

author: Potter
text: She went round the farm garden, nibbling off snippets of all the different sorts of herbs that are used for stuffing roast duck.

author: Potter
text: And she waddled into the kitchen and got two onions out of a basket.

author: Potter
text: The collie dog Kep met her coming out, "What are you doing with those onions?

author: Potter
text: Where do you go every afternoon by yourself, Jemima Puddle-duck?"

author: Potter
text: Jemima was rather in awe of the collie; she told him the whole story.

author: Potter
text: The collie listened, with his wise head on one side; he grinned when she described the polite gentleman with sandy whiskers.

author: Potter
text: He asked several questions about the wood and about the exact position of the house and shed.

author: Potter
text: Then he went out, and trotted down the village.

author: Potter
text: He went to look for two foxhound puppies who were out at walk with the butcher.

author: Potter
text: Jemima Puddle-duck went up the cart road for the last time, on a sunny afternoon.

author: Potter
text: She was rather burdened with bunches of herbs and two onions in a bag.

author: Potter
text: She flew over the wood, and alighted opposite the house of the bushy long-tailed gentleman.

author: Potter
text: He was sitting on a log; he sniffed the air and kept glancing uneasily round the wood.

author: Potter
text: When Jemima alighted he quite jumped.

author: Potter
text: "Come into the house as soon as you have looked at your eggs.

author: Potter
text: Give me the herbs for the omelet.

author: Potter
text: Be sharp!"

author: Potter
text: He was rather abrupt.

author: Potter
text: Jemima Puddle-duck had never heard him speak like that.

author: Potter
text: She felt surprised and uncomfortable.

author: Potter
text: While she was inside she heard pattering feet round the back of the shed.

author: Potter
text: Someone with a black nose sniffed at the bottom of the door, and them locked it.

author: Potter
text: Jemima became much alarmed.

author: Potter
text: A moment afterward there were most awful noises--barking, baying, growls and howls, squealing and groans.

author: Potter
text: And nothing more was ever seen of that foxy-whiskered gentleman.

author: Potter
text: Presently Kep opened the door of the shed and let out Jemima Puddle- duck.

author: Potter
text: Unfortunately the puppies rushed in and gobbled up all the eggs before he could stop them.

author: Potter
text: He had a bite on his ear, and both the puppies were limping.

author: Potter
text: Jemima Puddle-duck was escorted home in tears on account of those eggs.

author: Potter
text: She laid some more in June, and she was permitted to keep them herself: but only four of them hatched.

author: Potter
text: Jemima Puddle-duck said that it was because of her nerves; but she had always been a bad sitter.
